docs.lead_paragraph: When Rhoda Wright learned that the television assembly plant where she had worked for 27 years would close, she did all the right things. She helped to counsel fellow workers through their shock. She used her $13,000 in severance to pay off a car loan. And once the plant shut in April, she enrolled as an accounting student -- hoping to one day get back to her old wage of $10.60 an hour. But for all her energy and determination, a bleakness creeps into Ms. Wright's story. Her unemployment insurance will run out by next December, six months before she graduates. She expects to land an accounting job quickly enough, even at age 49, but only at $8 an hour. ''I don't have a clue anymore what our income is going to be,'' she said, ''but we'll get by. We always have.''

headline.main: Downsizing Comes Back, but the Outcry Is Muted

docs.abstract: Plant closings, layoffs and forced retirement are rising sharply again, but outcries and conflict that characterized waves of downsizing in 1980's and early 1990's are largely gone; labor unions, instead of protesting, are more likely to help laid-off members make transition to other jobs, often working in tandem with managers responsible for layoffs; for their part, corporate executives no longer call attention to downsizing as healthy for profits and stock prices; they express regrets much more often, blame global forces beyond their control, fatten severance packages for workers and announce layoffs well in advance of final day; recent layoffs announced by some major corporations noted; effects of downsizing on job market in central Indiana discussed; photo; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nick Polidore, a state gymnastics champion with bangs, dimples and baggy blue jeans, would seem as robust as any other 11-year-old. But he has asthma, so ragweed or a simple cold can propel him to an emergency room, gasping for breath. Once, an asthma attack would keep him in a hospital for a day or two. But since his family doctor here, Brandt S. Loev, took up disease management, a system for controlling chronic conditions like asthma, the big emergencies have stopped -- and so have the big bills to his mother's health insurance company.

headline.main: Managers of Care, Not of Costs

docs.abstract: Health maintenance organizations and insurance companies are shifting to better medical practice after having concentrated on cutting costs, especially by reducing doctors' fees, only to see profits evaporate; are focusing on management of chronic diseases, which accounbt for 60 percent of medical costs in US; movement is breeding new industry of as many as 300 companies that contract with HMO's and employers to supervise care of people with chronic ailments; photos (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, after a fitful night's sleep, Rochelle Saks had her last artificial insemination. Her medical plan does not cover infertility treatments, she owes her doctor almost $10,000 and she can afford to pay only a few hundred dollars a month to retire the debt. Thus, he has refused to continue treating her. ''I've been up since 2:30 in the morning, thinking this is our last try,'' Ms. Saks said before that final visit to the doctor. ''We cannot afford to go any further on our own.''

headline.main: The Fight to Cover Infertility; Suit Says Employer's Refusal to Pay Is Form of Bias

docs.abstract: Rochelle Saks of Mahopac, NY, is among small but growing band of plaintiffs who have filed class action complaints with Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, charging that denying medical coverage for infertility treatments is unlawful discrimination; there are estimated six million infertile couples in country; argument for coverage was bolstered by Supreme Court ruling in June, not directly related to infertility, that declared that reproduction is 'major life activity' and that, therefore, those who could not procreate are protected under Americans with Disabilities Act; idea of requiring coverage of infertility treatments is fiercely contested by insurance company advocates, business groups and some academics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: No, that silence emanating from the New Jersey State House isn't the symptom of some epidemic of legislative laryngitis. There's no mime contest going on, pitting the Assembly against the state Senate. The peculiar hush surrounding New Jersey's elected officials these days is actually one of the most time-honored forms of political shadow play: the nearly imperceptible sound of government officials beginning to raise their own pay. The state Assembly took the first surreptitious step late last month, by voting -- without debate -- to authorize a salary commission to study the pay of all three branches of government. Still, one of the sponsors of the bill, Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon, insists that the issue isn't pay increases for legislators, but pay equity for New Jersey's judges. Governor Whitman won't publicly address the issue until, and unless, legislators summon up the fortitude to pass a pay increase plan, according to her press secretary, Jayne O'Connor. But Ms. O'Connor made certain that the Governor's no comment explicitly stated Mrs. Whitman's aversion to the dreaded R-word, by volunteering that the Governor is not considering raises for members of her cabinet.

headline.main: What If the Legislature Really Deserves a Raise?

docs.abstract: David Kocieniewski column argues case for raising salaries of New Jersey legislators; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most taxpayers can find ways to pare their 1998 taxes, especially if they act now; once the year ends, many opportunities will be gone. ''There are some differences from last year because of changes in the law,'' said Avery E. Neumark, a principal at the New York accounting firm Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company, ''as well as traditional year-end moves.'' His checklist includes these strategies: SECURITIES TRADES -- After last year's ultracomplex rules on holding periods for long-term capital gains and losses, Congress has simplified the rules, defining long term as anything held over 12 months. Such capital gains will have a 20 percent tax rate for most taxpayers; up to $3,000 of net capital losses can be taken against ordinary income. While the Dow industrials have recovered in recent weeks, many investors still have paper losses in emerging-markets funds, for example. If you are among them and want to reposition that holding, recognizing the loss in December could cut your taxes. If the loss is more than $3,000, the excess can be carried forward to a future year. KEOGH PLANS -- Anyone with self-employment income -- even from a sideline like part-time consulting -- can put part of that money into a tax-deferred Keogh retirement plan, provided that the plan is set up by Dec. 31. The money does not have to be deposited until the due date of the return, April 15 -- or later, with an extension. CHARITABLE GIFTS -- If you donate appreciated securities instead of cash, you can deduct the market value and owe no capital-gains tax. If you are short of cash now, you can take a 1998 deduction if the charity charges the donation to a credit card in December. STATE AND LOCAL TAX BILLS -- For most taxpayers, paying real estate or fourth-quarter estimated state and local taxes in December will mean a bigger 1998 deduction. But if you are subject to the alternative minimum tax, you will lose the deduction, so then it may be worth postponing any payments until January. ESTIMATED TAXES -- The 1998 rules are not as tough as last year's, but you should still do some math to make sure you do not face an underpayment penalty. You will escape the penalty if your estimated tax payments come within $1,000 of what is due, or if you have paid 90 percent of the current year's liability in 1998 or an amount equal to 100 percent of your 1997 liability. HEALTH INSURANCE -- The allowed deduction for self-employed people has risen to 45 percent of health insurance premiums paid for 1998. That gives the self-employed a bigger incentive to buy coverage. FLEXIBLE SPENDING ACCOUNTS -- This employer-provided benefit reimburses expenditures for certain child-care and medical costs, tax-free. But it is a ''use it or lose it'' benefit, so you should tap any unused funds this month. GIFTS -- An individual may make annual gifts of as much as $10,000 to any number of people, with no reduction of the unified gift and estate tax credit. Wealthy people may want to consider making gifts before Dec. 31 to cut the size of their taxable estates. JAN M. ROSEN

docs.lead_paragraph: Lynn Amy Levoy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Levoy of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Brett Adam Pollak, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Pollak of Roslyn. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Ms. Levoy Pollak, 25, is the assistant fashion editor at New York magazine. She graduated from Boston University. Her father is an independent management consultant, specializing in health care. Her mother, Martha Levoy, is the coordinator of volunteers at Comprehensive Community Hospice of Parker Jewish Institute in Lake Success, N.Y.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jobless Rate Slips to 4.4%, Nearing 3-Decade Low Despite fears that 1998 still could turn out to be the decade's worst year for layoffs, more Americans than ever are working, the Government said. United States employers added 267,000 workers to their payrolls in November as the jobless rate slipped to 4.4 percent, near a three-decade low. It was the biggest gain in payrolls in three months and matched the pace of the year's first half, when many on Wall Street were more fearful of an overheated economy than of a recession. [Page A1.] Mylan Said to Face F.T.C. Lawsuit The Federal Government is preparing to accuse Mylan Laboratories, a big generic drug maker, of anti-competitive practices. The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has recommended filing a civil action against the company, which it said sharply raised the prices of its products after trying to corner the market on the drugs' raw materials. [A1.] Unocal Quits Pipeline Project Unocal has withdrawn from a consortium that planned an $8 billion energy pipeline system traversing war-torn Afghanistan, a company official said. The consortium, which brought together companies from Saudi Arabia, Japan, South Korea and Pakistan, had planned to build twin oil and gas pipelines from Turkmenistan to the Pakistan port of Gwadar. [C2.] Republic Hires Sears Marketer Republic Industries hired a top Sears, Roebuck marketing executive to be its president as part of its drive to raise the profile of its Autonation USA unit. John H. Costello, left, will be responsible for developing the marketing for the company, which owns the nation's largest chain of franchised new and used automobile dealerships. He will also oversee its retail and rental operations. [C2.] Hollinger Selling 45 Newspapers Hollinger International, the second-largest United States newspaper group, will sell 45 newspapers to Community Newspaper Holdings for $475 million. Hollinger said the papers to be sold are in 14 states. [C3.] Buyers Bid Up Ubid Initial Offer The stock of the on-line auction company Ubid ended the first day of trading with its shares closing at $48 -- more than three times the $15 offering price. Coming in the aftermath of several run-ups by Internet initial public offerings the last month, Ubid was able to offer the stock at a price beyond the original estimated range of $12 to $14. [C2.] Scottish Power in Pacificorp Talks Scottish Power was said to be discussing a deal to acquire Pacificorp, a big utility in the Northwest. The value of the potential deal was not known, but two British newspapers reported last month that Scottish Power wanted to buy Pacificorp for $6.6 billion. [C3.] $1.5 Million Award in Air Bag Death A Federal jury in Manhattan awarded $1.5 million to the estate of a 5-year-old boy killed after an air bag deployed in the front seat of a Dodge minivan where he had been riding without a fastened seat belt. DaimlerChrysler, the minivan maker, called the verdict unfair. [B2.] Struggle Over Kenya Beer Market The maker of Kenya's best-selling beer, which was named Tusker after one of the brewery's founders was killed by an elephant, is facing another behemoth. South African Breweries has taken on East African Breweries and its partner, Guinness, in what has quickly become a war over more than beer. [A4.] Mexico Bank Bailout Held Up After nine months of grueling debate, Mexican lawmakers have reached broad agreement on measures to refinance the Government's troubled $61 billion bank bailout. But a final accord has been stymied by a dispute over a top Government finance official. [A6.] Rises Fuel Insurance Spiral Many of the 16 million people under 65 who have to buy their own health insurance are facing increases of 40 percent or more this fall, creating a dynamic that appears likely to send prices even higher. [A7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: In the midst of a fresh wave of corporate downsizing announcements, the Government reported yesterday that more Americans are working than ever and that the overall economy continued to create jobs at a robust clip. While corporate giants from Boeing to Johnson & Johnson are planning to lay off tens of thousands of employees because of various business difficulties, American employers expanded their payrolls by an estimated 267,000 workers in November, the Labor Department said. Unemployment fell to 4.4 percent from 4.6 percent, coming close to the lowest rate in the last three decades.

headline.main: JUMP IN NOVEMBER SENT WORK FORCE TO A RECORD HIGH

docs.abstract: American employers expand payrolls by estimated 267,000 workers in November, causing unemployment to fall to 4.4 percent from 4.6 percent despite fresh wave of corporate downsizing announcements; job growth figures for September and October are revised upward; some 64.1 percent of all Americans of working age now have jobs, and American workers on average are earning 3.7 percent more than a year ago; factory workers continue to lose jobs in large numbers, but this is offset by gains in construction and service sector; graph (M)
docs.snippet: In the midst of a fresh wave of corporate downsizing announcements, the Government reported yesterday that more Americans are working than ever and that the overall economy continued to create jobs at a robust clip.    While corporate giants from...

docs.lead_paragraph: If Vice President Al Gore had expected that his incumbency and financial strength would discourage serious challengers, that assumption faded yesterday with Bill Bradley's announcement that he was likely to seek the Presidency in 2000. As of yesterday afternoon, Mr. Bradley was among a half-dozen Democrats who were talking about joining the Presidential hunt next year. But while the field might be relatively large, with Democrats stirred by the perception of the Republican Party in disarray, Mr. Gore continues to be viewed by Democrats across the country as the overwhelming favorite. And even in announcing that he might seek to challenge Mr. Gore, Mr. Bradley served to underline the difficulty that he -- and, for that matter, any Democrat -- is going to have running against a man so closely identified with a popular President.

headline.main: A Cautious Entry Into an Uphill Race Against Gore

docs.abstract: Expanding field of Democrats are seriously thinking about challenging Vice Pres Al Gore for party's Presidential nomination in 2000; crowded field will surely benefit Gore, who already has accumulated huge amounts of political good will and campaign contributions over the last seven years; photos of Gore, Bill Bradley, Rep Richard A Gephardt, Rev Jesse Jackson and Sens Bob Kerrey, John F Kerry and Paul D Wellstone (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Renee Couture earns about $21,000 a year as owner of a struggling Domino's pizza franchise in Danville, Ky. Single, 37, the mother of a 5-year-old daughter, Ms. Couture also has diabetes, though thanks to her health insurance from Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, she said, ''My diabetes is in the best control it's been in my whole life.'' Then, in October, Anthem notified Ms. Couture that it was more than doubling her premium, to $498 a month -- nearly 30 percent of her salary -- from $197, a little more than 10 percent.
docs.abstract: Many of the 16 million Americans under 65 who must their own health insurance face premium increases of 40 percent or more; their premiums are rising at least twice as fast as group-policy premiums and are even rising faster than health care costs at start of 90; increases are expected to lead the youngest and healthiest members of this segment to drop their health insurance, shrinking the insurance companies' pool of policyholders and driving premiums up further for those left; photo of Renee Couture, a single mother, who earns $21,000 a year and whose premiums are going up to nearly 30 percent of her salary (M)
